top_comment.text:
I had every intention of bringing home an older cat because I didn't want 
the hassle of an energetic destructive kitten. When I got there and saw Mu 
who was a few months old i fell in love and had to take him home. i feel 
bad for not taking an older cat but i am still glad i gave a cat a second 
chance, or a 3rd chance in Mu's case as he was adopted out and brought 
back. ﻿
top_comment.author: bec goesbananas

comments.text:
Rosie went for her last checkup in January and received a clean bill of 
health. Will take her back again early next year for another checkup and 
will do the teeth when I can scrape together the cash. I just need to get 
her a new carrier that opens from the side. Thanks for your concern.
comments.author: Jessica Cejnar

comments.text:
+Jessica Cejnar she needs to go to the vet for a checkup and update her 
shots at least once a year, get her teeth cleaned (for much more than just 
clean teeth) and your veterinarian can recommend a worm prevention program 
for your cat. so important for her to see her vet at least once a year to 
keep her healthy. plus your vet can possibly catch an illness or minor 
injury early that might become serious or even life-threatening if left 
untreated. sorry to preach, just know from experience what can happen if a 
cat, or any animal doesn't have a regular checkup by a vet.
comments.author: Kathy Dempsey

comments.text:
I should say the only other time I had to take her to the vet was a few 
months ago. I did take her for a checkup about a month after I adopted her 
and again when she had the rabies shot.
comments.author: Jessica Cejnar

comments.text:
Maybe you don't see the magic in a kitten, but there was just something 
about Rosie's LOUD purr that made me fall in love. She was already fixed 
and up to date on her shots except for rabies. The only time I had to take 
her to the vet was a few months ago when she had worms. She's 3 years old 
now.
comments.author: Jessica Cejnar

comments.text:
I thought the same and adopted a 2-year-old cat. I don't see the magic in a 
kitten destroying your furniture and needing shots more often than adult 
cats do, they're going to grow up in no time anyway.
comments.author: marelicainavokado

comments.text:
I'm the same way. I had every intention of adopting an older cat, but my 
Rosie, who was 2 months old at the time, literally reached out and grabbed 
me. I currently can't have more than one cat, otherwise I would totally 
adopt an older cat.
comments.author: Jessica Cejnar

comments.text:
+MetalMemory Don't temp me lol. I thought about it but honestly I couldn't 
afford a second animal in the house.
comments.author: bec goesbananas

comments.text: It's never too late to adopt another one : )
comments.author: MetalMemory

top_comment.text: One day, if my cat die,what should I do?﻿
top_comment.author: brian wong

comments.text: Good idea.
comments.author: brian wong

comments.text: have a good cry.
comments.author: reptilian water type

comments.text:
we all die eventually, the point is to enjoy the journey and help him/her 
be comfortable if that should happen.
comments.author: Daedronus

comments.text:
I guess it depends i how you deal with grief everyone does in a different 
way. Don't feel like you need to get another right away because it could be 
bad for you and your knew cat but once you feel you've moved on a little 
from the pain of losing your other pet try getting a knew pet, however 
don't expect them to be identical or similar to your late cat as this could 
cause tension. What I'm prone to doing us after a few years and my pet is 
getting on the years I'll purchase another pet they may learn the good 
habits you want easier and you'll get used to there personality without 
expecting them to be like your old pet, of course it still is hard and four 
years later I'm not over my latest deceased pet, just trust in the fact 
that you gave them the best life that you could and that they were happy in 
the end. Sorry got a bit ramblly
comments.author: Yukki Katsuki

top_comment.text: Any advice on how to get my cat to stop knocking over her water dish?﻿
top_comment.author: Lynn Mix

comments.text:
That was a big problem I had with my Simba too, he loved to tip over the 
water! First I got a little heavier bowl, a porcelain one, but he still 
managed, so I went all out and got this ridiculously huge double bowl 
that's meant for a big dog, and it's too big and awkward for him to pull 
over now, lol! Whatever works!
comments.author: Carolyn Walker

comments.text:
My cat has been doing this lately as well!!! She still drinks from it but 
sometimes she'll just walk over to it and hit it or the mat it's on and 
spill water then walk away... -_- like wtf lol I know cats don't do things 
out of spite, but I want to know WHY she's doing that... haha
comments.author: Leah Wall

comments.text:
I'd just get a plastic one with a wide bottom or a "cylinder-shaped" 
ceramic bowl. Mine doesn't even wanto to drink from her bowl anymore, she 
just goes into the bathroom and waits for me to turn on the shower because 
she wants running water.
comments.author: marelicainavokado

top_comment.text:
I have a sister who is 13 years older than me. She has never been a good 
pet owner... Some of the last pets she had lately were two female cats. One 
died due to disease and the other stayed as a single cat.

My sister then shacked up with a horrible man, and only one of this man's 
many flaws is the fact that he doesn't like cats. My sisters cat, Teka, was 
then confined to the kitchen area, on top of the cabinets or on her bed 
under the table. The family members weren't allowed to touch her because of 
her shedding fur, and she wasn't allowed to even meow at my mom when she 
went to visit. One thing you should know about Teka: she is the sweetest 
cat EVER. I have never seen her growl, hiss, bite or take a swat at ANYONE, 
no matter how annoyed or threatened she feels.

Around this time of the year, two years ago, my sister wanted to take her 
whole family away on vacation for a week and asked me to go over and feed 
the cat. You should know that I have two cats who have been raised in the 
company of other cats, so they are fairly social. So I told my sister "no". 
I would not go over everyday, on purpose, spending my precious gas, to her 
house to feed the cat. Instead, why couldn't the cat have a vacation of her 
own and come here? I was sure there wouldn't be any problems, because I 
know my cats and I know Teka, and they would get past the weirdness of a 
new acquaintance in a matter of days. And so it was.

I was home alone for three weeks as my whole family went on vacation, and 
it was up to me to watch the cats (it's my favorite time of the year!!). 
For the first two or three days there were a few hisses here and there 
(from my cats - Teka didn't hiss or growl, not even once), but then Teka 
and Zita, my youngest, started getting closer. They'd run together 
throughout the house every morning and play joyfully. I told my mom Teka 
was having such a good time that she suggested to my sister that Teka could 
stay the rest of the month as an extended vacation - my sister agreed.

Two weeks passed, and Teka had become inseparable both from me and from 
Zita. Teka would sleep with me and follow me everywhere I went, and she and 
Zita would run together and play fight everyday, even laying down for a nap 
together and grooming each other. She was so much happier now... I told my 
mom this... and she agreed we couldn't send her back to her miserable life 
with my sister and her companion. So my mom suggested we could take her in 
permanently... and of course my sister didn't put up a fight. She wasn't 
that attached to Teka, and she and the kids could always come and visit her.

Teka was 6 years old at the time, she is now 8, and she is my baby. She is 
my shadow, follows me everywhere (even to the bathroom... I can not poop 
unescorted, and I know many of you can relate), sleeps with me, kneads and 
drools on me. She doesn't do it with my mom... just me. I'm her person. She 
has a happier expression, a happier and healthier life, and even my other 
cat Zuka, who is much more independent, plays with her sometimes. We have 
never seen a sweeter cat, and to this day I still have yet to see her 
growl, hiss, bite or swat her paw at us for any reason.﻿
top_comment.author: lilithmarleen

top_comment.text:
My wife and I adopted an older cat that we new was sick. she was just 
sitting there alone in a cage. we had about three days with her before 
finding out she had aggressive cancer and was in a lot of pain. we were 
able to there in her final moments. at least she had the comfort of human 
contact as she passed on. It was a real honor to be her guardian for the 
few days we had her. it can be a hard road to travel but giving older cats 
a home is very rewarding. definitely worth the tears and vet bills.﻿
top_comment.author: Blindmansworld

top_comment.text:
I have two amazing almost for year old cats I have raised since 8 weeks. 
Neither of them are aggressive except with each other. They are scared of 
other cats that enter the yard . They never became aggressive but they are 
defensive if needed. They are inside babies now. Both when seeing a kitten 
at the vets office seemed curious. The kittens were in the cages waiting to 
be adopted and both my babies seemed very interested not threatened or 
aggravated at all. An adult cat entered our yard and was clearly trying to 
befriend them and they were simply scared. Would it still be a good idea if 
I was to adopt another cat to go for an older cat? ﻿
top_comment.author: Jill Linkous

comments.text:
+Jill Linkous true I'm used to my kitten lol not even fazed by the car but 
that's because I fostered him from a week. You could always do a two trial 
:) take a cat home for a week or two and see how that goes
comments.author: tigger1995Magi

comments.text:
That would stress mine out completely. My boy moans so heartbreaking In the 
car. Taking them anywhere accept the vet is not an option . Luckily mine 
never have been sick so vet only for yearly checkups. And it breaks my 
heart . But nice idea though.
comments.author: Jill Linkous

comments.text:
You could always take your cats to a shelter/rescue group and put them in a 
private room to meet a cat and see how that goes. Some times getting a cat 
to meet its new family member at home can often not work out very well. If 
things seem if iffy but your heart is set on a certain cat than you can try 
and do regular visits just to get them used to each other that way. Maybe 
swapping them around in carrier, i.e. your cats are able to walk around a 
cat in a carrier and then vica versa
comments.author: tigger1995Magi

top_comment.text:
Anyone have any tips on if you can tell if you'r cat may be partially 
blind?﻿
top_comment.author: Grayfirewolf forest

comments.text:
In one of "Cat from Hell" episodes the cat has cataracts.  Her second 
eyelid came half-way up her eye.  Jackson has lots of helpful information 
in his show.  My bf and I have been watching the old ones on Netflix.  I 
highly suggest it.
comments.author: CorakiOG

comments.text:
Wait until the cat is facing away fron you and click your fingers behind 
her ears and see if she turns round.  Also mention it to the vets at the 
next visit as they can check the eye for damage.  Sometimes you can see a 
clouding in the eyes much like cataracts in people.
comments.author: PurdyBear1

comments.text:
+Alina Chen thank you for the tip, i have had concerns about since he was a 
kitten (he is 2) he ran into things alot, is very skittish about being 
approached even though he has NEVER been hit in his life, he is wary about 
jumping on things even if its only a bit higher than he is. He only jumps 
on the cat tree after it was here for a long time, plus he spends a lot of 
time hiding. So I am just curious thanks for the tip.
comments.author: Grayfirewolf forest

comments.text:
You can try to fake punch your cat. (It's like a punch but your not really 
making physical contact with your cat) then see if it blinks. I would go to 
the vet if you want to be sure. And if it is only partially blind maybe 
there's a cure! I hope your cat stays strong and healthy!
comments.author: Alina Chen

comments.text:
+Marta Capdevila Oriol Your dog was Inu, that is "dog" in japanese, and 
your cat's name is also in japanese. Otaku detected? :D I was about to name 
my cat Neko, but then I decided for Toulouse :)
comments.author: nosoynadaoriginal

comments.text:
I always been a dog person, even If I was the only person in my family who 
loves cats, when I left my parents house the past February, I adopted a 
german sheperd puppy (I had it until past November) but then I had to move 
to another apartment, and Inu my dog, I had to give him to a family, that 
family has a house near the beach and two daughters, He is better this way. 

The next days feels like shit, I always had a pet in my life and then none. 
Then I remembered the words my father always tell me when I was little: "If 
you want a cat, when you live on your own, you can have one " And I said to 
myself, why not? 

Mery one friend of mine who has two cats, she advised me of having an older 
cat not a kitty 'cause it was my first cat, So I went to a shelter and it 
was madness, there was like 25 or 30 cats in there! And I was decided to 
take one with me at all cost, The only thing I could think was: I don't 
wanna be alone again in that empty apartment. 

It don't take me long, 'cause a very friendly cat started follow me around 
in the shelter, purring me. and he not knew me at all!

I was so happy (I cried a little I admit) he was the first cat to purr me ( 
Today he is always purring me!  The firsts days I had problems sleeping 
because of that xD but now I can't sleep without his purring.
  
He have 3 years old, He was rescued when he had 1 year old, severely 
injured, because some "Gitanos" (I'm from Spain) were hitting him with 
rocks, and he stayed in the Shelter 2 years until I arrive. And took him 
with me.

I named him "Taro" in japanese means "First born" He is and always will be 
my first cat :)
comments.author: Marta Capdevila Oriol

top_comment.text:
In November last year I finally persuaded my mum to let me adopt a cat 
(after our previous cat Chloe passed away). I was originally wanting to 
adopt a cute cuddly kitten but eventually we decided upon a 7 year old who 
we have named Minnie. We used allot of advice from this channel and from 
"My cat from hell" and she has grown from a very shy cat who would hide 
from almost everyone to a confident and very cheeky cat who has a lot of 
love to give. Thank you for your tips Jackson, and I totally recommend 
considering adopting an older cat! :D <3﻿
top_comment.author: Abbie

comments.text:
THANK YOU!

I go to shelters every now and again because I am looking for my first best 
friend; I have already been watching Jackson and learning all I can, and I 
wind up giving the SHELTERS advice! For example, There was this one cat who 
was adopted as a kitten, and there was a four year old in the home. The 
parents didn't stop the four year old from pulling her tail, ears, and 
whiskers. When I got there, she hid from me... it was a cramped space 
shared with two other cats. She was barely a year old... I used slow blink 
and she came right to me, started purring, and even playing! She was barely 
a year and a half old when I met her. I wish I could have taken Snowball 
home, but people like you and your family give me hope that she will find a 
great home. <3 

Please do me a favor? After you read my comment, please give Minnie a bit 
of love for me, and have a beautiful, blessed day!
comments.author: SashaNT

comments.text: woohoo!
comments.author: joyjoyoo

captions.text:
Kids, you just have
it all handed to you.

And let me just
tell you something,
it's all about kittens.

Kittens, kittens--
oh, I want a kitten.
So sweet.

Please, let me have a little
ball of fuzz, a little kitten.
What about the older guys?
What about them?

Let me tell you something,
youngster, you better

go out there and
catify the world!
Now, get out of here.

Yesterday I went to this
wonderful woman's house, Janet.
Hi Janet.
She's fantastic.
She's a great artist.

And she's also a caretaker for
many elderly and special needs
cats and dogs.

I mainly wanted to
talk a little bit

today about the benefits
of adopting an older cat,

slash dog, slash pony,
slash bunny, whatever.

First of all, they demand
less and they give more.

That I can tell you by
my experience, and maybe

my friend Janet, and
anybody else who specializes
in older animals.

They can tell you, man,
these guys are grateful.

You will find that the love that
you get from an older animal
is just unparalleled.

And I'm not just
saying this, guys,

I'm not just saying
this because I

want to go out there and be just
like my friend Janet yesterday.

And take the hard to place guys,
take the ones that are older,

take the ones that may
have higher vet bills.
Yeah.

I mean I get it, it might
be an inconvenience.

And also psychologically
may be very tough for you.

But that said, the payback
is absolutely immense.

Secondly, by and
large, they tend

to be less willfully
destructive.

Less in the way of marking, or
if they don't get their way,

they pee somewhere and they
can scratch up everything.

Now, of course, they may
have physical problems

that we see manifest
in older cats.

But in terms of
behavioral problems,

I see a lot less when it
comes to older versus kittens,
teenagers, and middle age.

So let's talk about older
cats and your household.

If you work a lot,
you don't really

want a kitten in your
house, or a teenager.

They're going to be
demanding of you.

You've seen me do a lot
of videos on play therapy,
on getting energy out of cats.

A 9-year-old, 10-year-old
cat, you don't really

have to worry that much about
constantly entertaining them.

Of course, we want to keep
them mentally stimulated,

and physically
stimulated as well.

But that doesn't mean
they demand it the way
younger cats do.

Once you get to
a certain age, it

is about the path
of least resistance.

And that makes for a much
calmer house for the most part.

Because instead of hunt, catch,
kill, eat, groom, and sleep,

it's like watch someone
else hunt, catch, and kill.

And then you can eat
and groom and sleep.

That is the life
of an older cat.

That's like what cat
retirement is all about.

Another advantage to an
older animal in your home--

when you get an older
cat, a senior cat, you
know what you're getting.

You know if they have a history
